Award.AwardTitle: UNS:Erythrocyte-derived optical nano-vesicles as photo-theranostic agents

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Anvari, Bahman
Proposal No.: 1509218

The unique contribution of this proposed work is the ability to engineer nanoparticles that can be made using the patient's own erythrocytes to extend the circulation time and minimize biocompatibility issues so that these nanoparticles can interact with tumors. Light energy can then be used with the nanoparticles to generate heat and provide localized hyperthermia at the tumor to destroy it or augment chemo or radiotherapy. Personalized medicine has great potential and this work can make important contributions to this field.

Effective treatment with a minimum of side effects of various malignant tumors remains an important problem in modern medicine. Personalized medicine gives the opportunity to direct and optimize such treatment to individual patients based upon their genetic and immunological makeup. This proposal will develop ghost erythrocytes loaded with fluorescent dyes as theranostic agents to image cancer cells by fluorescence and also to induce photothermal killing damage. The erythrocytes will be functionalized with an antibody to target tumors in vivo in xenograft mouse models. The PI has had many under-represented students in his lab. Aspects of the work will be incorporated into a new class.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The specific objectives of this project were: (1) To engineer optical particles derived from red blood cells, with optimum formulation of the comprising near infrared dye (indocyanine green) and its concentration so that the fluorescence quantum yield (brightness) of the particles would be maximized. (2) To determine the circulation dynamics and biodistribution of the engineered particles in mice models. (3) To assess the effectiveness of the particles in image-guided photo-destruction of tumors in mouse models. All of these objectives were achieved.

Intellectual merit: (1) We did rigorous characterization of the physical and optical properties of the particles as a function of their diameter, method of fabrication, and concentration of the dye material (indocyanine green). (2) We developed methodologies for functionalization of the particles with specific antibodies and molecules, and demonstrated the efficacy of the functionalized particles for targeted imaging of ovarian cancer cells. (3) We characterized the circulation dynamics and biodistribution of micro- and nano-sized particles in mice. (4) We demonstrated the efficacy of the particles for imaging and photo-destruction of tumor implants in mice.

Broader Impact: (1) Four graduate students (including one female student) obtained their PhDs on research activities related to this project.  Additionally, this project provided opportunities for involvement of 11 undergraduate students and 7 high school students in the research activities. (2) Some of our results were published in 11 peer-reviewed journal articles. Additionally, we presented some of our results as 6 conference papers, and as 21 abstracts for presentations at local and national conferences.(3) Some of our research findings were incorporated in a graduate level Bioengineering course (BIEN 245, Optical Methods in Biology, Chemistry, and Engineering). (4) The project led to collaboration with other investigators in the field to investigate the potential utility of these particles in vascular imaging.
